Award.AwardTitle: Biocompatible Metal (Core)-Layered Double Hydroxide (Shell) Nanoparticles for siRNA Delivery

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET-0829128
K. Rege, Arizona State University

The overall objective of this collaborative research is the engineering and mechanistic understanding of biocompatible core (gold nanorod)-shell (layered-double hydroxide or LDH) based nanoparticles for selective delivery of siRNA with an eye towards enhancing hyperthermia treatments. Specific segments in the proposed nanoparticle are dedicated to (1) hyperthermic ablation and (2) carrying siRNA for inhibiting heat shock protein response to hyperthermia. The proposed research, therefore, employs bottom-up nanoscale engineering for direct impact in biomedical problems.

LDH structures are a class of inorganic ceramic materials with the general formula M2+1(1-x)M3+(OH)2.(An-)x/n.mH2O, where M2+ is a divalent cation, M3+ is a trivalent cation, and An- is the interlayer anion of valence n. The unique LDH structure readily allows the intercalation of anionic molecules (e.g. siRNA) via ion exchange; varying the ratios of metal ions results in the tunable loading of siRNA in these nanoparticles. Nanoscale LDH shells may be generated using physiologically necessary metals (e.g. iron and zinc), thus obviating toxicity-related concerns. Furthermore, the disintegration of the LDH shell at late endosomal / lysozomal (acidic) pH results in an environmentally-responsive platform.

The primary objectives are: (1) synthesis and characterization of gold nanorod-LDH nanoparticles with narrow size distribution profiles, (2) generation of siRNA-loaded core-shell nanoparticles, and (3) in-vitro evaluation of siRNA delivery and combination treatment using core-shell nanostructures. Simultaneous siRNA delivery and hyperthermic ablation on a single nanoparticle are unique attributes of the proposed platform, and can significantly enhance therapeutic efficacies for the ablation of cancer cells. Successful completion of the proposed research will result in a platform that can be extended to diverse biomedical applications.

The proposed research, at the interface of nanotechnology and biomedical sciences, synergistically combines principles from nanoparticle synthesis, hyperthermia, surface chemistry, biomolecular adsorption, and cell biology, and is intended to have a direct impact on biomedical sciences in the near future. Graduate students will be trained in the application of nanotechnology in the biomedical sciences resulting in well rounded, interdisciplinary training in engineering and biomedical sciences. The educational thrust is also on the recruitment of underrepresented populations and women in graduate studies in engineering as exemplified by the graduate students currently in our respective research groups. In addition, the PI has recently initiated collaboration with Down-to-Earth Science (DES), an NSF-funded GK-12 project at Arizona State University (http://gk12.asu.edu). The PI and Co-PI, and the graduate students will partner with the director, staff, and graduate students of the DES program in bringing the biomedical benefits of nanotechnology into K-12 classrooms through lectures and web-based education tools. The proposed research will also have a significant impact on undergraduate education with a particular emphasis on the biomedical benefits of nanotechnology. Six undergraduate students, including four from the Barrett Honors College, in the PI's laboratory and two undergraduate students in the co-PI's laboratory at ASU exemplify our commitment to encouraging talented students to pursue research opportunities and graduate studies in engineering. All undergraduate students in the PI?s laboratory are recipients of the Fulton Undergraduate Research Initiative (FURI) award from the Ira A. Fulton School of Engineering at ASU which is a unique program that encourages undergraduate research in engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
0829128 Project Outcomes Report

 

Background and Significance. The overall objective of this research is an investigation into biocompatible core-shell nanoparticles that are able to simultaneously administer hyperthermia (high temperatures) and nucleic acids (e.g. siRNA) to cancer cells. Resistance of cancer cells to different treatments is a significant biomedical challenge. As part of this research project, we carried out fundamental studies on multifunctional nanoparticles for cancer cell ablation using hyperthermia (high temperatures) and molecular delivery. To this end, we proposed studies on gold core-layered double hydroxide (LDH) shell nanoparticles for accomplishing these goals. Gold nanoparticles possess plasmonic and photothermal properties which can be employed to convert light to heat, while the LDH shell can be used for encapsulating molecules for delivery to cells. 

 

Intellectual Merit. The proposed research employed bottom-up, nanoscale engineering with an eye towards applications in cancer. The focus of the research on layered double hydroxide (LDH) was on the understanding of coprecipitation and structure evolution in order to reproducibly synthesize monodispersed nanoparticles (NPs) with controlled mean particle sizes. The evolution of the (Zn, Al)-LDH nanostructure from coprecipitation to hydrothermal treatment was monitored using electron microscopy, electron diffraction, and zeta potential measurements, in order to investigate nanoparticle formation mechanisms. Biocompatibility, drug delivery efficacy, and cellular uptake of LDH NPs were studied. Valproic acid-intercalated LDH NPs showed improved efficacy (~30 fold) over valproic acid alone in pancreatic adenocarcinoma BxPC-3 cells. We also carried out in-depth studies on gold nanoparticle based systems for the delivery of nucleic acids to cells. We first investigated the stability and corresponding photothermal response in biologically relevant media, and also developed a new synthesis method for increasing the yield of gold nanorods. We also investigated how stable gold nanorods present in the extracellular space outside cancer cells can be used to kill them when activated by near infrared light. We carried out mathematical modeling studies in order to understand the temperature rise and concomitant cell death following near infrared activation of the gold nanorods. Furthermore, we carried out studies on delivery of nucleic acids for transgene expression as well as gene silencing using gold nanorod cores functionalized with polymers. We investigated how light activation could result in the release of drugs from gold nanorod-based matrices for synergistic destruction of cancer cells. Recently, we also compared different nanoscale morphologies – e.g. nanorods vs. nanospheres – for delivery of nucleic acids. Future work will involve robust synthesis of Au core-LDH shell NPs; systematic studies on the optimization, heterogeneous nucleation, nanostructure evolution, and cellular delivery will also be necessary.

 

Broader Impacts: Our research groups are involved in cutting-edge research at the interface of materials science, nanotechnology, nucleic acid / drug delivery, and cancer, resulting in next-generation scientists involved in trans-disciplinary research and training. This research has led to more than fifteen publications in peer-reviewed journals and has had a high impact as demonstrated by citations to this work. Our joint review manuscript on inorganic nanoparticles has received almost ninety citations since the short time it was published, indicating significant interest in the broader scientific community.
